Posts.Content: Hi Tracey I had a TRAM recon which is using the muscle and tummy fat.  I was in bed for the first two days(in hospital a week as well) and am still not back to work.  I had it done in Aug of last year.  I don't won't to worry you as part of the reason I'm not back is trying to get my head round the whole cancer thing as everything happened so quickly at the start. The nurse is right in that it will take around three months recovery and depending on your job, you may be off for longer than you wanted to be. Hope that is some help?
Posts.Title: ld flap Reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi there You are slightly the wrong way round, the TRAM(I've had it in Aug) is the one where they use muscle and fat still all attached and feed it under the skin and restitch it into place as the new breast.  It is indeed a hip to hip incision but I believe that part is the same for the DIEP where no muscle, just fat is used.  Not sure which is the longer recovery but all I can say having had the TRAM is that some five months later I am still not back to work and still have the tightness and discomfort around the tummy area.  Very pleased with the look of the new breast I hasten to add. Hope this clears some confusion?
Posts.Title: ld flap Reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Mistymoley That was my original plan of treatment too.  Cancer always like to have the last say! They don't do that stats thing over here unfortunately but then maybe they do when you get passed onto the oncology team.  I never had that because of no further treatment which was a shame as I wanted to hear the stats(I know not everyone does), There is more than one hospital but for now I'm going to content myself(or try) with the knowledge that they know what they're doing.  I shall be beating the GP's door down if I feel anything new or worrying though. Thanks again for you reply.
Posts.Title: No further treatment....worried!

Posts.Content: Thanks for your reply, you made me laugh out loud(literally) with your breakfast comment so thanks for that! Unfortunately I live in Northern Ireland so am stuck for a second opinion as not many options.  I was told it was discussed in the multi disp meeting so not just the Consultant's opinion.  You are right about everyone's case being different as I've come across so many who had the same size lump, operation etc and they are having completely different treatment so have to trust the experts I suppose. Thanks again for your response. Chris
Posts.Title: No further treatment....worried!

Posts.Content: Hi Karri Thanks for your reply.  I think I was just going through a wobbly weekend still feeling sorry for myself after the recon.  I've rationalised it better today in that I have to trust they know what they're doing all I'll spend the rest of my life worrying
Posts.Title: No further treatment....worried!

Posts.Content: Hi Dorothee Thanks for taking the time to reply and I'm sure you are right.  They said that I may have marginal breast tissue left but that if anything else developed in that breast I would feel it straight away as it would develop near the surface.   I was told to feel empowered that I had found the first lump myself(just as well seeing as the mammogram picked up none of the three lumps! I'm telling myself that they really do know what's for the best and trying hard to believe it.   Thank you again for your reply.
Posts.Title: No further treatment....worried!

Posts.Content: Hi all you lovely people here, I appreciate that this might seem a bit strange but I am worried!  I have had a mastectomy three weeks ago and immediate Tram reconstruction.  Altogether they found three very small lumps(biggest one 8mm) and a 5 cm area of pre cancerous cells.  All lumps were grade two and positive for oestrogen and progesterone but negative for the HER thingy. My dilemma is that they are offering me no further treatment!  No radio or chemo.  Part of me is delighted but part of me is terrified.  I feel that I wanted even radio as a reassurance.  Whilst I know that they are the experts I feel now that I've been discharged from the whole breast cancer thing with hormone therapy and left to sink or swim!   I know I should be grateful but why don't I feel grateful? Why do I spend hours worrying about not feeling completely cured?  I'm sorry if I sound silly compared to what a lot of you are going through on the site and I do really feel for you... Chris
Posts.Title: No further treatment....worried!

Posts.Content: Hi G n" J Thanks for you help..
Posts.Title: Pain in the mastectomy reconstruction.

Posts.Content: Sorry I meant this post to go in the post breast cancer group but not sure what I've done!  Can one of the moderator's reply and move this over to the other sub group?  Sorry...
Posts.Title: Pain in the mastectomy reconstruction.

Posts.Content: Hi there Wonder could anyone reassure me or is having a similar problem?  I had a TRAM immediate recon in Aug two years ago which I was very pleased with.  In the last few days I have had sharp pains in the side of the breast just suddenly come on, no reason for it and then after a few second it goes.  I stopped wearing my underwired bras in case it was causing a problem.  They are not very frequent but have put me back in that awful 'worrying' place that I don't want to be in. Could it be scar tissue, does scar tissue cause sharp pains?   Would love to hear if anyone else has had pain two years post off and should I rush to the doctors?  if I go to the GP it makes it seem more worrying.. Chris
Posts.Title: Pain in the mastectomy reconstruction.

Posts.Content: Hi Mistymoley thanks for reply. I'm hoping it is that or scar tissue pain but to be on the safe side I have an appointment with the consultant on Friday just to get it checked!   Thanks again!
Posts.Title: Pain in the mastectomy reconstruction.

Posts.Content: Hi Kipper Felt compelled to answer your message to say what an amazing understanding surgeon he/she is!  I couldn't have put it better myself and want to send this onto friends and relatives. Although one is usually surrounded by relatives and friends throughout this, no one truly understands the whole thing.  My relatives and friends want the old me back now that I've had my surgery and recovering.  It's so hard to explain to them that the old me is gone and they and I have to get used to the new me.  I am still so emotionally fragile but don't want to burden them.  I visited my two sisters last week and they both never mentioned the whole cancer thing.  It was like the elephant in the room, don't talk about it and it never happened.  Not that I want to drone on about it but I need to talk about it a bit. I'm waiting for counselling with the lovely Macmillan people so hopefully that'll help me sort a few things out in my mind. Love to all you lovely people on this site and hope you can be as well as you can throughout this xmas time.
Posts.Title: Friday the 13th is upon me - feeling lonely

Posts.Content: I am just over a year from treatment for hormone positive breast cancer and got my first all clear a month ago.  I am on Arimidex and this morning noticed a small amount of nipple discharge on my pyjamas on my 'good' side.  I have googled(yes I know I shouldn't!) side effects of Armidex(which I have been taking for nearly  year) and it doesn't seem to be a side effect. I am freaking a little even though I got the all clear last month.  Anyone else had a similar thing happen? I will ring my breast care nurse but they never get back for 24-48hrs.
Posts.Title: Nipple discharge

Posts.Content: Hi G n J You;re quite right about google, would never have found this brill site if I hadn't used the pesky tool. No redness, flakiness or irritation just slight discharge, small amount but enough to send me into panic mode again.   Awaiting call from BC nurse but know form experience that it may take them up to 48 hrs to get back to me. Thanks again..
Posts.Title: Nipple discharge

Posts.Content: Hi there wise people, I applied for copies of my medical notes in relation to my recent treatment and have leant that my tumours were 8/8 positive to both oestrogen and progesterone. I knew they were positive but can anyone tell me the significance of the result(if there is indeed any!) of it being 8? Good wishes to all on this wonderful site, such inspirational stories every day!
Posts.Title: Hormone positive receptors..

Posts.Content: Hi Panther Thanks for reply and yes you're right, google is not always a friendly tool.  I did google side effects of Arimidex hoping that it would show up as a side effect but it didn't but what I did see concerned me enough to post here. Message left with BC nurse so back to the waiting game..
Posts.Title: Nipple discharge

Posts.Content: Thank you all for your replies, it's like learning a new language(not one we wanted to learn of course!) My consultant was of the old school and told me nothing hence applying for my notes. When I asked her when I was first diagnosed what type of breast cancer I had her reply was, "you've got breast cancer"!
Posts.Title: Hormone positive receptors..

Posts.Content: Thanks to both of you for your reply. Intreprid, I have learnt a lot from your lengthy reply!  I'm now assuming that my four previous years on HRT were feeding the three little blighters and they were having some party on it!  I do regret taking it for so long but felt so well on it.   I am on Arimidex as I am post menopausal and if I can take it for up to 10 years I will.  I do have side effects, the crushing tiredness and some joint pain but as you say if it is keeping me clear of the hormones then Its a done deal. Thank you again for your kind replies.
Posts.Title: Hormone positive receptors..

Posts.Content: Thanks Mistymoley for your prompt reply.  I don't have any other sign of hypothyroidism but I will get it checked.  I think it's just a blood test isn't it? It's like just when you think you can slowly start to breathe out and relax after the whole BC thing, it reminds you who's in charge... Have left a message on my breast care nurse's answer phone so will await her answer but feel I am going to end up back at the hospital...
Posts.Title: Nipple discharge

Posts.Content: I have an appointment tonight to see Consultant so only one more day to wait... I've forgotten what it's like to not have anything to worry about.
Posts.Title: Nipple discharge

Posts.Content: Hi Dorethee, thanks for your reply and yes you're right, we immediately suspect the worst.  I think that's how BC leaves you.  Losing that trust you once had in your body is something I am still getting used to. If I hadn't bought a new set of shorty pyjamas due to this weather I probably wouldn't have noticed it for a while as they are a darker colour than my other nightwear so noticed it the first time I wore them. Thank you again..
Posts.Title: Nipple discharge

Posts.Content: Hi Michele I had a mastectomy and immediate reconstruction using the tummy muscle and fat just over three weeks ago and although, obviously I can't answer your query about the shrunken area in your back, I can answer about reconstruction a few weeks ago.  I am the same as you in that I can't walk far and I feel like I'm walking like an old women.  My boob is still very swollen and feels alien to me as in it doesn't feel like part of me at the moment.  It is so tender, tight and numb that It feels like it's someone elses boob if that makes sense! I have been told that this whole thing will take 3 months to fully recover from and like you I feel sorry for myself at times and frustrated at the lack of improvement.  I think we just need to be easier with ourselves and let our bodies do the recovery thing in their own time, hard I know but I think it's for the best. Were you given any exercises to do post op?  I wasn't and it worries me a little as I feel I should've been but am not back to the hospital again for another two weeks. You're entitled to feel a bit sorry for yourself, you've been through a lot.. C
Posts.Title: Following Mastectomy and Reconstruction

Posts.Content: I would ring the GP in the morning and ask to speak to one of the GP's as I was told you have to be seen within two weeks by a Gynea specialist for any type of post menopausal bleeding.  I was seen by the GP that following day and had an appt within the two weeks to see about it. Hope this is of some help.
Posts.Title: Who you gonna call?

Posts.Content: Hi Poemsgalore I am 53 and had bleeding around 9 months after taking this.  I had been changed from one type to another the previous month but am definitely menopausal as a blood test confirmed this before i started taking the drug(i had previously been on HRT for a few years so had no idea what my hormones were doing). I was sent to see a Consultant Gyneacologist and had a minor op to have a look but all looked normal.  I think you should visit your GP and let them make the decision.
Posts.Title: Bleeding on Anastrazole

Posts.Content: Sorry should've finished off by saying it only lasted around 5 days then just stopped.
Posts.Title: Bleeding on Anastrazole

Posts.Content: Hi there Holmlea I had one reconstruction using the diep method but also my muscle as well.  I am 14 weeks post op and only now is it starting to settle.  The swelling will settle but remember it's major surgery and takes longer to all fall into place then you think.  Well done for getting through it..
Posts.Title: DIEP surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Stoksie I am coming up 8 months past diagnosis and mastectomy and taking Letrazole and I to have pain in both hips, well more discomfort more noticeably in bed at night.  I spoke to my GP about it as like you I had no chemo or indeed radio.  When I mentioned to me consultant at the time when told I would have no more investigations(never had a scan or MRI) just treated the mastectomy and hormone treatment, about the pain in the hips(sorry that was a ridiculously constructed sentence there), she told me that if I hadn't previously attended my GP with it, it was nothing to worry about!   The upshot was that I went back to my GP and told her about the bone discomfort and all she offered me was an X-ray which of course showed up nothing.  I agree that worry doesn't help recovery or one's state of mine when I am trying to return to work.  I just want a bone scan for peace of mind but think due to the NHS and cuts they won't give me one. Ask your GP, it's always worth asking.  I am going to sit on it(literally!) for another couple of months as i was told that on the Letrozole I would be called for a scan in the first twelve months.  Do you think that is the same type of bone scan that can eliminate secondaries?  Is that where your ostea problem was diagnosed? Good luck with your GP
Posts.Title: Bone scan

Posts.Content: Oops my cancer was ER+8 as well, didn't know that that was one thing to avoid.  I'm the same age as you and I think it is partly age related as well.  I honestly don't think shaving will make much difference and as you say, it'll be a long wait.  I did at one stage consider getting extensions put in at a clinic that specialises in hair loss but chickened out thinking that it may do more damage than good in the long run. I always said if it got that bad then I'd just wear a wig but thankfully it has settled and I know I'm probably playing with fire(I also use oestregen pessaries with advice from my Oncologist, jury is out on whether they get into your blood stream but the bigger picture is quality of life) It's hateful this whole cancer thing!
Posts.Title: Letrozole, hair thinning and shaving

Posts.Content: I've tried the whole gamut of lubricants and find them all so unnatural and wet!  I'm not prepared to give up on my sex life so use the eostregen pessaries when my partner is about.  He works abroad for a lot of the time so obviously I don't need them all the time.  I read up on loads of studies and talked at length with both my very supportive GP and Oncologist and they were both happy for me to use them sparingly. I also had a total abdo hysterectomy with everything removed in May of this year.
Posts.Title: Letrozole, hair thinning and shaving

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca I have been on the same drug just a year behind you and am finding the dame thing(I have short hair and blonde which thankfully does not show up as thinning so obviously).  Even before Cancer I would've have a tendency to fine hair as the hairdresser's now like to call it. I take crushed flaxseeds in my porridge every morning and don't know if it's a coincidence but it does seem to have slowed down the shedding.  I remember that you are a super healthy eating so probably already take flaxseeds in some shape or form but if not, it's worth a try.
Posts.Title: Letrozole, hair thinning and shaving

Posts.Content: Hi Jowan Hope you don't mind be joining this thread but I felt compelled to answer you as I am sort of in your situation albeit behind you somewhat.  I found a small lump at the top of the breast around a cm in size(I'm 52 btw) and went to the dr not overly concerned as I'd had my first mamo in the screening program less then two years ago. Appt got quickly and they told me after the biopsy that it was cancer.  Completely broke down as my GP after examining me had said she didn't think it was concerning...had a lumpectomy and node removal and when I went back for the results there was good and bad news.  Good in that the lump had clear margins and nodes but bad in that when the surgeon was in she'd seen a nodule and took it out along with other tissue well away from the original lump and he came to early cancerous DCIS.  I couldn't believe that I'd been unlucky enough to have two separate sorts of cancer in the same breast.  I am waiting until thurs once they've had their mutil disp team meeting to discuss and have been told to consider a mastectomy.  I was shocked to hear this(as anyone would be) and initially told myself that I wouldn't go ahead with it.   I'm only having radio btw, no chemo which I'm relieved about.  I have come round to the idea of a mastectomy and am now considering it seriously.  I am a worrier, and I shall feel like my breast is a ticking time bomb.  I know they monitor you afterwards but I am concerned even with this as my original lump wasn't picked out on a routine mamo. It's good to hear that you are recovering well from the operation.  And you are right in what you say, people, men included, will take you as they find you.  No one gets to our age without some kind of war wound or scarring.  I am divorced with a 12yr old son and recently in a new relationship with a lovely man and he is taking this well, too well I sometimes think.  He was remarkably calm about the idea of a mastectomy, far more than I was. He lives an hour away so I am trying to be a bit more independent and taking myself to the appointments and keeping the important ones for when I need someone. Please keep in touch, this group is amazing and I've only been on it for a few days but I am a big talker! Chris
Posts.Title: Just joined and would like some advice

Posts.Content: Hi Dilly You are slightly behind me in that I had a small lump removed on 1st July and they also found early cancerous DCIS which was completely separate from the main small lump.   I can see that you have already had an in depth reply above this about what to ask and I can't really add anything else to that very thorough response!  Can I ask if you don't mind, how yours was discovered?  And what size it is?   You will be surprised(hopefully!) how well you'll recover from the surgery and make sure you do your exercises four times a day to keep the arm moving well. Best wishes to you and stay in touch? Chris
Posts.Title: newly diagnosed dcis

Posts.Content: Hi there Yes you sound very similar to me.  I have been told just radio and tamoxifen although I am 52 and due to HRT(off it now of course) not sure whether I've passed the menopause or not.  Am assuming they'll do a blood test on me. How did you find the mastectomy?  Did you recover well?  Did you have reconstruction at the same time or are you having it later?? Questions, questions, sorry! Chris
Posts.Title: newly diagnosed dcis

Posts.Content: Hi Judith I am on Arimidex which is essentially the same drug as yours and also suffer from insomnia, hot flushes(less so now, started drug in Sep last year) and vaginal dryness.  As if cancer wasn't enough! My GP changed my presription a few months ago to your one and it very quickly made me miserable and constantly nauseous, awful!  Rang GP and said couldn't continue with this brand and they changed me back.  I have just collected my new prescription and yet again they have given me the Teva brand of Anestrole.  I spoke to the pharmacist about it and she said the drug i was on is made my Astro Zeneca and is around 15 times the price of this one!  Hence why they keep trying to push me onto this one. I have decided to give it one more go as I want to be sure it was the drug causing the side effects then if is was I'll be better armed to tackle the GP again. Kate I was given hormone pessaries to counteract the dryness(my cancer was highly hormone receptive) but my GP said it was ok to take them.  I haven't dared try them yet as i really want a definitive answer as to whether it's safe to take them.  My consultant is a dragon who says no to everything so pointless asking her. Can you throw any light as to whether it would be ok to use them?
Posts.Title: Anastrozole & Depression.

Posts.Content: I'm on day five of starting Arimidex which I think is in the same family as this.  Can anyone tell me when and if the side effects will kick in?  I was getting hot flushes anyway before I started it due to coming off my HRT but so far nothing.  Keep expecting to wake up with sore bones etc.
Posts.Title: Aromasin side effects

Posts.Content: Goodness, Vicki, that's awful about your husband's family history.  It is just something I would like to look at in the fullness of time. I didn't have a CT at all.  My lump was very small, less then a cm.  I had a mammogram less then two years ago which was disappointing that it didn't pick it up but they said that it was probably because my lump is at the top of the breast and just outside the mammogram area.  I just went in and had the lumpectomy with margin and nodes removed.  Both the margin and nodes came back clear which was a huge relief but that's when she said she'd discovered the second cancer in an area far away from this lump but it is early stages of non invasive ductal in situ I think it's called. I have been sent away for a week while they discuss me at their meetings and I have to consider a mastectomy or more surgery.  The more I think about it, the more I am coming round to a mastectomy.  I will then have radiotherapy, no chemo and 5 yrs of hormone therapy. I am also considering going on a dairy free diet having researched it.  Have you heard about this? C
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed..

Posts.Content: Hi again G and J I just hope you're right about the oncology team being a little nicer to deal with.  And thanks for the reassurance about my nodes.  I know it all sounds good but they will never give you odds or statistics at my hospital and I can't help thinking about all the people I know who know of people where it came back.  Normal worries I suppose. I was told that it probably wasn't linked to my HRT but more to my paternal aunt who had a bilateral mastectomy at the age of 37(35 years ago still alive to tell the tale).  I'm not so sure though.  Want to get tested for the BRCA gene as I've two younger sisters so there maybe consequences for them. C
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed..

Posts.Content: Hi Vicki You sound like you've been diagnosed around the same time as me.  It's hard to believe so much can happen in such a short space of time.  And great that you also have clear nodes.  You are also having radio like me later on.   I am 52 and was happily on HRT for around 4-5yrs and considered myself low risk as like you I don't smoke, only drink occasionally, well within normal weight range and breast fed my son for the first 8 months.  Do you have any family history?  i have recently found out that my dad's sister had a bilateral mastectomy at the age of 37 due to bc but don't know whether it was in both her breast and she just opted for total mastectomy or not.  She's in her early 70's now but sort of estranged from the family so can't really find out much more info. Do keep in touch.. Chris
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed..

Posts.Content: Hi there, I posted in the general group and have now found this one which is more specific. I was diagnosed with breast cancer around a month ago and have had the wide local excision and sentinel node thingy.  I got clear margins and no node involvement which I was greatly pleased with but they had a hoke about and removed a nodule and other tissue and have found early changes in the cells showing ductal carinomal in situ which has freaked me a little!  Is it rare to have two forms of cancer going on at the same time in the same breast? I should say I'm 52 and healthy(well I thought so!).  They have discussed further surgery with me or to consider a mastectomy.  I was shocked at first but now think it may be better as I am a worrier and will always feel like the breast is a ticking time bomb.  But then what of the other breast? Is there anyone here who has had similar?  I am having radiotherapy only and tamoxifen as the main lump(under a cm) is estrogen positive. Would be grateful to chat with others just boarded the cancer train and feel like they're in for a hell of a ride... Chris
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed..

Posts.Content: Hi George and Jackie and again thank you so much for your prompt response.  It means a lot to 'chat' to people on the same journey whether they are nearing the end, middle or beginning! The lumpectomy wasn't for ductal, just plain old common invasive but it was only due to the surgeon hoking about and seeing a suspicious looking nodule further away from the isolated lump that she took tissue out.  I appear to have two sorts going on in the one breast(not like me to be different, much!)  She said it was very early cell changes indicating that and that it would take years to break out and become invasive.  They seem happy enough with the small lump not to need chemo but it still freaks me out that there may have been a few stray cancer cells circulating round me as we speak.  She said I don't need an MRI scan or bone scan, just radio.   I need to ask my nurse on thurs about this HER thingy as I haven't been told.  All I've been told is the main lump is stage on, grade 2 and the DCIS is very early cell changes.   My nodes were all clear for which I'm very thankful.  I have been told I'll be on Tamoxifen which confuses me slightly as I am 52 and i thought you were only on it if you were pre menospausal?  I have no idea where I am as I was happily on HRT for the last 5 years(hindsight,eh?) Thank you again and best wishes to you in your soon to be end of said train ride(does it ever end??) Chris
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed..

Posts.Content: Hi Wendi Thanks for coming back to me so promptly!  It sounds like you are a few stops ahead of me on this cancer train ride.  How did you find the mastectomy?  Probably a silly question but I mean in terms of recovery etc.  If I do go that way I believe I can't have reconstruction until radio is completed.   You are right about everyone being treated in a completely different way.  My consultant(nickname ice queen), does not really 'do' questions.  When I asked her after the core biopsy what type of cancer I had, her reply was 'it's breast cancer"!  I've have settled on a truce and just pump the nurse for info after our consult.  I have heard she is the best so no point in moaning about her communication(or rather lack of) skills.  You are right about this whirlwind.  I feel I have very quickly had to learn a new language with this whole cancer thing.  I sometimes feel it hasn't quite hit home as I have hardly cried much(not like me!)  I am going for counselling with this wonderful organsisation as I am lucky they have a centre in Belfast close to my hospital.  I can't really talk to my sisters whom I am close to as I don't want to upset them.  My newish partner is lovely but he is too damn positive for my liking sometimes about the whole thing and I feel like screaming at him sometimes 'I've got cancer!"  I'm entitled to feel a little self reflective and sorry for myself at times. I wish you well in your upcoming chemo and will tune into your posts as well. thanks again Chris
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed..

Posts.Content: You've made me get out one of the leaflets and read the side effects again!  It gives hair shedding as the second most common side effect, ie 1 in 100 people.  As I mentioned before I have had this problem on and off since my 30's with lots of things affecting it so it probably isn't the drug but just me! I am definitely more tired and could(and do) fall asleep in the early evenings if I don't stop myself but as i am still off work I don't mind that.  I think the side effects are far less then Tamoxifen so am glad that I was post menopausal. Thinking of you all out there going through this awful disease....
Posts.Title: side effects of letrozol

Posts.Content: Hi there both of you I started this drug around six weeks ago and as you say not much mentioned here.  I am finding(touch wood!) little but easy managed side effects.  I am tired more but then it may be due to surgery still.  My hair is shedding a little but then I have always had that problem on and off so was annoyed to see it as the number one side effect!  This also may be due to surgery and just my normal shedding.  I haven't had chemo.  My knee joints are also a bit achey but apart from that I can cope with the drug.  If it keeps me alive for the next ten years then I am more than happy. I am 52 and they did a hormone profile(I'd been on HRT prior to discovering the cancer) and found me to be post menopausal and haven't had a period so that's all good.  I do get awful hot flushes as well but I got those after coming off the HRT and they have continued since June.  Again they are not the awful ones that involve night sweats thankfully. I fully intend to take it for the ten years that's now recommended and after reading about Tamox I am glad to be on this drug.
Posts.Title: side effects of letrozol

Posts.Content: The side effects are manageable with the help of paracetamol.  Not sure how I'm going to deal with the tiredness when I return to work though.  it reminds me of early pregnancy tiredness, could fall asleep at the drop of a hat!  I was told that the side effects took 3-6 months to 'bed in' and may improve after this?
Posts.Title: side effects of letrozol

Posts.Content: Hi Kay Can I ask why a sex life is difficult on Tamoxifen?  I am going on it after treatment(mastectomy and radiotherapy). I agree with the comments you made about telling a potential man at the start.  I asked my boyfriend of three year what he thought and he agreed it would be good to know at the start.  If it puts men off then it's put the right type of man off that you wouldn't want to know in my book! Chris
Posts.Title: Dating again after breast cancer?

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca Wow, looked at your blog and was surprised how good they look!  Can I ask a few questions if you don't mind?  Am I right in thinking I can't have an immediate reconstruction as I am having radio(no chemo I believe)?  What type of reconstruction was yours?  How do they ahem, give you nipples?? Sorry but I am at the start of the journey and want to hang onto as much of my former life as possible throughout the procedure. Any tips appreciated.. Chris
Posts.Title: Dating again after breast cancer?

Posts.Content: Hi Gill As someone who is over the other side of a mastectomy I wonder could you help me?  I am 52 and in a newish relationship of around three years(the last year really being a proper serious relationship) after a looooong marriage.  I've had a lumpectomy but they discovered a second type of cancer cells so am probably going to have a mastectomy shortly. My new man is so far being lovely about it all but I know the realities are not quite what you think they're going to be.  I am very open about my body but suspect this will change after the op and am frightened that it may put him off sex etc.   He is nearly being too good about coping with it all am am worried that the shock will settle in with both of us once I've had the op. Should I think about trying to find after photos to show him or would that be difficult?  I can't have the reconstruction straight away as I'm having radio. Chris
Posts.Title: Dating again after breast cancer?

Posts.Content: Hi there I just joined the group yesterday and although I can't really help much, felt the need to reply.  I am in a sort of similar situation to you only I am 52yrs old.  I had surgery, lumpectomy with clear margins and clear nodes but they discovered a second type of cancer early cells, ductal carninoma in situ.  I have been told they are discussing me at a meeting but to prepare for a mastectomy. Having had surgery already i was confident that it was sorted but then that's cancer for you, a mind of it's own. You are younger but I would be guided by the surgeons.  They are the experts and you have to give them the credit that they know what they're doing.  They would not have suggested a mastectomy lightly.   This whole thing is a scary thing and I know that you feel like you've entered an alien world that is nothing to do with you.  You are not alone feeling like that. I know I haven't been much help but talk to your breast care nurses as well, they are very genned up on it all. Best of luck Chris
Posts.Title: How do I get advice and support?

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona Just realised that you have joined the group, oops! C
Posts.Title: How do I get advice and support?

Posts.Content: By the way, Fiona, join the breast cancer discussion group, you'll get a lot more responses.  I was advised to yesterday. C
Posts.Title: How do I get advice and support?

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona Am glad you're getting a few responses now, I was like, and desperate to get some responses to my original post yesterday but I think someone was right in saying that most are enjoying this good weather(it's cloudy today in Northern Ireland though) I would take someone with you and write down questions.  It all helps to remember the responses tomorrow.  And make the most the the nurse, they are amazing at explaining stuff. I felt like that after reading other peoples experiences as well but we are all going through the same disease just different strains of it. Hope all goes well tomorrow for you. Chris
Posts.Title: How do I get advice and support?

Posts.Content: Your body fat makes small amounts of oestrogen as well even if you have no ovaries or womb.  Even if you are post menopausal your body still makes small amounts of oestrogen. Hope that helps!
Posts.Title: Understanding the reason why I might be on tamoxifen when I've had...

Posts.Content: Hi Cathy I was like you and needed no further treatment.  I had a small lump, lumpectomy where a second lump was found and then advised to go for a mastectomy.  Good job as a third small lump was discovered after this.  All lumps were grade 2 and less then a cm.  No nodal speed so was told after the multi discip meeting that no further treatment was needed.  I was a bit shocked as I nearly would've preferred radiotherapy as a precaution afterwards.  But it was explained that they would not put me through it if I didn't need it. You have to trust that they know what they're doing and not only that, it is discussed with a number of experts, not just the surgeon. I don't think they're are any specific questions to ask apart from asking them to go into detail why no further treatment is required. All the best.
Posts.Title: 6week check up tomorrow after ld reconstruction
